title: What are some interesting and easy books to read about semiconductors? - Quora

response.answer_text: The best introductory textbook I’ve come across is “Semiconductor Device Fundamentals” by Robert Pierret. Semiconductor Device Fundamentals: Robert F. Pierret: 9780201543933: Amazon.com: Books This book starts with a very gentle introduction to semiconductor theory, and then goes onto basic devices like p-n junction, bipolar junction transistors (BJT), the ubiquitous Metal Oxide Semiconductor Field Effect Transistors (MOSFETs) and Metal Semiconductor junctions. This book is excellent, and I still refer to it from time-to-time. Once you’ve got the hang of the basics of semiconductors and simple devices, and you want to answer deeper questions- why do these semiconductor crystals have bandgaps? How do LEDs/ laser diodes etc emit light(quantum wells)? How do electrons behave in a material (in bulk and 2D quantum wells) with respect to energy distributions? How are solids formed? To answer these questions, I’d recommend “The Physics of Semiconductors: With Applications to Optoelectronic Devices” by Kevin Brennan. The Physics of Semiconductors: With Applications to Optoelectronic Devices: Kevin F. Brennan: 9780521596626: Amazon.com: Books This book also deals with III-V semiconductors like Gallium Arsenide and Aluminium Arsenide (and their alloys). When different materials are grown on top of each other to vary the potential, you can do really cool things with them which can’t be done with silicon, such as high performance transistors (HEMTs and HBTs), light emitters like LEDs and laser diodes and photodiodes tuned to a specific wavelength.

I wish we had a modern equivalent of “The Golden Book of XXXX” but we don’t. Some of this is because the subject gets “physics and math” deep pretty quickly. For example: An Introduction to Semiconductor Physics, Technology, and Industry http://users.ece.gatech.edu/%7Ealan/ECE6451/Lectures/ECE6451L1IntroductionToElectronicMaterials.pdf https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/electrical-engineering-and-computer-science/6-012-microelectronic-devices-and-circuits-fall-2009/lecture-notes/MIT6_012F09_lec01.pdf These are consider “introduction level”. :-[ One that got me interested in the subject many years ago is the 1977 special issue of Scientific American - it’s still one of the most approachable intros IMO. I still have my original copy! For a fairly non-technical discussion that isn’t talking about the current reality, it’s good. Scientific American Volume 237, Issue 3 Scientific American September 1977 Scientific American, Vol. 237, No. 3, September 1977: Amazon.com: Books Perhaps I should write a book?
